newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil to annualize interest rates as of 1998.
newsitem.headline: Brazil to annualize interest rates as of 1998.

text.p: Brazil's Central Bank said it will make its monthly-based Selic overnight rate an annualized based rate as of January 1998.
It also said the Central Bank's Basic Interest Rate (TBC) and its Basic Assistance Rate (TBAN), currently monthly based rates, will also be set in annualized terms.
The current monthly effective Selic overnight rate is 1.63 percent. June's TBC rate is 1.58 percent, while the TBAN is 1.78 percent.
Francisco Lopes, the Central Bank's director of monetary policy, told reporters the measure is aimed at stimulating the use of annualized rates in the market.
Lopes believes the annualized rates are a step toward eliminating the market's obsession with basing yields from short-term investments on monthly inflation.
"To evaluate real interest rates every month no longer makes sense," he said.
Lopes also said the government has only taken that measure because domestic interest rates "reached a compatible level."
Real interest rates fell from an annualized 30 percent in 1995 to about 17 percent in 1996. They are projected to fall to about 13 percent this year.
By adopting the annualized rates system, the government also shows that Brazil's stabilization program is on the right track, he added.
